urn:contentItem:6DWY-0XP3-RVS7-S4S5-00000-00Black Forest homeowners worry of fire risk from 40-acre vacant property filled with dead trees2025-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:17:28ZLexisNexisBlack Forest homeowners worry of fire risk from 40-acre vacant property filled with dead treesBy Tyler Cunnington(KRDO)

Click here for updates on this story

BLACK FOREST, Colo. (KRDO) -- At least 24 people have died after a string of wildfires sparked in the Los Angeles area. The destruction has brought fire danger to the forefront of many Coloradan's minds, including right here in El Paso County.

Homeowners in Black Forest reached out to KRDO13 Investigates about a property that borders theirs, which they say is filled with dozens of acres of dead trees. They're concerned that the property is a perfect source of fuel for a wildfire.

The 42-acre property is located at 9050 Burgess Road, which extends about a mile up the road towards Hardin Road.

That's where Rick Christie and his wife have lived for six years. He can see the Burgess Road property from his back deck. Christie says he's watched over the course of the last two years as the wooded area has become infested with Mountain Pine Beetles, which has caused them to rot and fall over.

That same area seen here on the Colorado State Forest Service's Forest Health map in 2023, as having 41 acres of Mountain Pine Beetle infection.

It now has Christie concerned about the 'tinder box' butting up agains his backyard, which is especially worrisome as Hardin Road residents were met face to face with the Black Forest Fire in 2013.

Christie says he bought the property well after the fire torched through the area, but he was told that the wildfire had spread right up to his back deck, singing parts of it, while leaving behind blackened bark on the trees in his yard, still visible to this day.

An El Paso County spokesperson on Tuesday, however, told KRDO13 Investigates that they have no jurisdiction over private properties, adding:

"El Paso County has no enforcement mechanism specifically for the bark beetle, or picking up dead wood off of private property. The Colorado State Forest Service says that the beetle is a native species that will alter forests but not destroy them. They play a part in helping to naturally thin forests out, preventing even greater problems from happening during potential wildfires."

An El Paso County spokesperson did suggest that a complaint could be filed with the County's code enforcement team, to at least put the issue in front of them and see what they could look into.

Meanwhile Black Forest Fire District, which is stationed just over a mile away down the road from the controversial property, tells KRDO13 Investigates they were not specifically aware of the 42-acre parcel and the swath of dead trees on it.

Now he wants to know what can be done to make sure this property is taken care of, if at all.

"There's got to be something that we can do, just to relieve the nervousness that we have." he stated, initially pondering whether the county could do something to mitigate the risk.

One of their wild-land crew members explained, similarly, that they are not allowed to go onto private property to do mitigation, nor do they have the manpower to send crews to do mitigation for people's property, even if it were permissible.

For Christie, he says he considered taking legal action against the property owner due to what he and several neighbors along Hardin Road alleged has been a reckless spread of the Mountain Pine Beetle from the neglected property, costing them tens of thousands of dollars to remove dozens of dead trees from their yards.

He ultimately decided against it, due to the cost for litigation and the uncertainty he'd be able to definitively prove the neglect of the property.

It's a property that Christie says has remained undeveloped, since he says it was bought five years ago.

The El Paso County Assessor's database shows that the property is owned by "Rabah Holdings LLC", which included a mailing address for a law firm in Colorado Springs.

KRDO13 Investigates called that firm to ask about their client. The firm stated that they were no longer a registered agent with Rabah Holdings LLC as of November 6, 2023, and instead provided an Organization ID# for them through the Colorado Secretary of State. Our search of that ID, turned up empty.

However, an entity with that same name was found in the Wyoming Secretary of State database, which initially filed in 2019, and has a renewal as of January 2, 2025. The mailing address for the LLC was to a P.O Box in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. They were most recently registered with a Personal Injury firm in Cheyenne, Wyoming.

2025 JAN 28 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Transportation Daily News -- Current study results on aviation have been published. According to news originating from Beijing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The real-life disaster simulation training based on virtual simulation technology for the participants plays an important role in the optimization of aviation rescue command structure,staff training,and the practical applications of tactical methods."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Beihang University: "In this paper,the mission-progress-step-scene(MPSS)model based on the discrete event modeling for setting up the collaboration training points in the aviation emergency management is proposed. The virtual simulation of aviation emergency management is conducted based on the virtual open scenario(VOS). The performance of the crews in the collaborative training is assessed comprehensively by using report-evaluationagree-do(READ)method. A helicopter forest fire fighting mission is developed based on the aviation emergency management virtual simulation collaboration training system,and verified with experiment."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results show that the complete process of 'mission modeling-mission training-training assessment' is formed,which can assist in rescuer training of other missions and improve the capability of participants in aviation emergency management."
For more information on this research see: Research on collaboration training techniques based on virtual simulation for aviation emergency management. Hangkong gongcheng jinzhan, 2024,15(6):268-278. Mar. 24—CO Troy Fondie (Orr) reports angling activities remain light but he anticipated a return of snowmobilers following the weekend snow.

CO Sean Cannon (Cook) checked ice anglers, monitored area forest roads and ATV activity, and checked for spring trapping activity.

CO Aaron Larson (Tower) worked primarily angling activity, including checking for anglers targeting crappies on Lake Vermilion. He also checked snowmobiles on lakes as the snow brought some activity back out. Ice conditions vary greatly with some spots remaining thick and other spots wide open on area lakes. He also fielded wildlife complaints and assisted DNR firefighters with a forest fire investigation.

CO Marc Johnson (Hibbing) primarily worked ATV and angling activity. Recreational activity has taken a significant downturn in recent weeks as the seasons change, he reports.

CO Duke Broughten (Aurora) monitored ice fishing activity and reports that recent cooler weather slowed lake ice from deteriorating. Anglers reported moderate success for panfish. Few ATVs were encountered.

CO Sean Williams (Ely) reports angling activity slowed again and the few anglers seen reported very little success. Violations included angling with no license in possession and a fish house on the ice after the legal deadline.

CO Hudson Ledeen (Hovland) reports most anglers had little to show for their efforts, but some folks hit pay dirt and landed some quality trout. He reports that lake travel remains good and likely will hold up for the remainder of the trout season.

CO Anthony Bermel (Babbitt) reports lots of people were out chasing crappies, with some success noted. Enforcement action included fishing with an extra line, litter, driving a vehicle on a prohibited trail and failure to display ATV registration.

CO Megan Franzen (Silver Bay) reports that ice anglers were reporting varied success.

CO Trent Anderson (Tofte) reports that anglers enjoyed easy walking conditions on area lakes.

CO Don Murray (Two Harbors) reports most lakes are still were holding good ice, but conditions can change quickly. North Shore streams started flowing this week with areas opening and becoming ice free. Spring closures have started on some forest roads and trails.

CO Vinny Brown (Northome) checked anglers targeting burbot, perch and panfish; patrolled forest roads and checked state forests for any decorative materials theft; and answered trapping, turkey and small-game-related questions.

CO Jayson Hansen (Bigfork) worked off-highway motorcycles, ATVs, small-game, and fishing activities; patrolled area trails; responded to wildlife-related complaints; and answered game and fish-related questions.

CO Mike Fairbanks (Deer River) checked anglers, monitored off-highway vehicle activity and assisted with motor vehicle crashes. Enforcement action was taken for allowing illegal operation of an ATV and off-highway vehicle registration issues. Fairbanks and his K9 partner Fennec also assisted in K9 handler interviews for the county sheriff.

CO Thomas Sutherland (Grand Rapids) reports many fish were biting in his area, drawing many out-of-state travelers. He took enforcement action for not properly licensing a fish house and not properly registering an ATV. He also is giving out road-killed deer permits as the local deer population is taking to the road ditches to eat grass.

CO Brian Holt (Grand Rapids) checked anglers and recreational vehicles, checked trapping activity, followed up on open cases and investigated a wolf depredation complaint.

CO Derek Peterlin (Brookston) investigated a report of anglers possibly targeting northern pike out of season. He received complaints of unlawful ATV operation within the city of Duluth. He also investigated a grass fire and took enforcement action for a repeat off-highway motorcycle violator. He also attended an ATV safety open house event at RJ's Sport & Cycle.

CO Tony Elwell (Cloquet) patrolled ATV-use areas, monitored spring forest road closures, conducted spring fish run patrols and took injured animal calls.

CO Mikeena Wehr (Carlton) patrolled for late ice angling activity, and for ATV and off-highway motorcycle activity. During a detail in the Nemadji State Forest she took enforcement action against riders on closed forest roads and trails. The forest is closed due to spring thaw and the trails and roads are being damaged due to unauthorized use. She asks people to stay off the closed roads and trails so use is not further delayed.

CO Aimee Hand (Willow River) monitored forests for activity. Spring beaver trapping is also starting to pick up. Enforcement action included failure to display registration and operating a motor vehicle in a closed forest.

CO Gabriel Soriano (Hinckley) responded to multiple grass fires. Wind and dried vegetation has created an environment for fires to burn out of control rapidly, he noted. Multiple ATV riders were located on closed forest roads and trails, resulting in enforcement action being taken.

urn:contentItem:6DK0-35B1-JBSP-10XM-00000-00Jiangxi Normal University Researcher Has Provided New Study Findings on Meteorology (Estimation of Understory Fine Dead Fuel Moisture Content in Subtropical Forests of Southern China Based on Landsat Images)2024-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:17:28ZLexisNexisMETEOROLOGYJiangxi Normal University Researcher Has Provided New Study Findings on Meteorology (Estimation of Understory Fine Dead Fuel Moisture Content in Subtropical Forests of Southern China Based on Landsat Images)


2024 DEC 04 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in meteorology. According to news reporting from Nanchang, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "The understory fine dead fuel moisture content (DFMC) is an important reference indicator for regional forest fire warnings and risk assessments, and determining it on a large scale is a critical goal."


Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Jiangxi Normal University: "It is difficult to estimate understory fine DFMC directly from satellite images due to canopy shading. To address this issue, we used canopy meteorology estimated by Landsat images in combination with explanatory variables to construct random forest models of in-forest meteorology, and then construct random forest models by combining the meteorological factors and explanatory variables with understory fine DFMC obtained from the monitoring device to (1) investigate the feasibility of Landsat images for estimating in-forest meteorology; (2) explore the feasibility of canopy or in-forest meteorology and explanatory variables for estimating understory fine DFMC; and (3) compare the effects of each factor on model accuracy and its effect on understory fine DFMC. The results showed that random forest models improved in-forest meteorology estimation, enhancing in-forest relative humidity, vapor pressure deficit, and temperature by 50%, 34%, and 2.2%, respectively, after adding a topography factor. For estimating understory fine DFMC, models using vapor pressure deficit improved fit by 10.2% over those using relative humidity. Using in-forest meteorology improved fits by 36.2% compared to canopy meteorology. Including topographic factors improved the average fit of understory fine DFMC models by 123.1%."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The most accurate model utilized in-forest vapor pressure deficit, temperature, topographic factors, vegetation index, precipitation data, and seasonal factors. Correlations indicated that slope, in-forest vapor pressure deficit, and slope direction were most closely related to understory fine DFMC. The regional understory fine-grained DFMC distribution mapped according to our method can provide important decision support for forest fire risk early warning and fire management."
For more information on this research see: Estimation of Understory Fine Dead Fuel Moisture Content in Subtropical Forests of Southern China Based on Landsat Images. Forests, 2024,15(11). (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/f15112002.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Zhengjie Li, Key Laboratory of Poyang Lake Wetland and Watershed Research, Ministry of Education, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang 330022, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Zhiwei Wu, Shihao Zhu, Xiang Hou, Shun Li.

urn:contentItem:6FJ7-V763-S6G4-44C5-00000-00SAVING HISTORIC MOUNT WILSON AND CRUCIAL COMMUNICATIONS FROM EATON FIRE2025-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:17:28ZLexisNexisSAVING HISTORIC MOUNT WILSON AND CRUCIAL COMMUNICATIONS FROM EATON FIREStates News ServiceWASHINGTON

The following information was released by USDA Forest Service:

Amanda Monthei

April 7, 2025

At just under 6,000 feet, the Mount Wilson Observatory and communication site sit within the San Gabriel Mountains of the Angeles National Forest in Southern California. Mount Wilson is known in Pasadena for its stellar views of the night sky and scenic backcountry trails. Drivers can actually see the trails and extensive network of critical communications from Interstate 210 nearby.

Fortunately, all of this infrastructure and access would come in handy when the Eaton Fire approached the southwest perimeter of Mount Wilson on Thursday, Jan. 9.

Unexpected but not unprepared

Forecasts hadn't anticipated how quickly the Eaton Fire would reach Mount Wilson that morning. But by 9 a.m. on Jan. 7, it became clear firefighters would only have a few hours to prepare rather than a day or two as previously forecast.

Unusually strong Santa Ana winds brought prevailing 80-100 mph downslope winds that devastated Altadena and other nearby urban areas. But just two days later, most of the fire's spread was occurring in the canyon southwest of Mount Wilson, rather than in the urban areas below.

Two federal firefighting teams Kings River Hotshots and Angeles National Forest Engine 310 as well as an array of state and county resources worked quickly to strengthen the fire's perimeter. To withstand the approaching fire front, everyone prepared for a strategic firing operation to create a buffer along Mount Wilson's southern edge.

Preparing for a strategic firing operation entails creating fuel breaks near structures, roads or other infrastructure, making them easier to defend when fire reaches them. First, excess fuel is cut away with chainsaws. Then, to add an extra layer of protection, crews use drip torches to burn the remaining vegetation. This creates a buffer or a void of burnable vegetation before the main fire arrives.

"We did a little bit of defensive firing, but it was a very light amount," said Brad Rafeedy, a fire management officer from the Klamath National Forest and a branch trainee on the Mount Wilson portion of the fire. "We're talking about three folks here, so just three drip torches. We wanted to use very little fire when fuels are in the critically dry condition that they're in right now. It doesn't take a lot of fire, especially when you have the winds that we had."

Crews had already been cutting as much brush as they could from below the parking lot and towers as the fire burned in the drainage below Mount Wilson. As the fire pushed up quicker than anticipated, fire leadership brought in Kings River Hotshots from the Sierra National Forest to perform a small strategic firing operation below the communication infrastructure.

Quick thinking and the right resources

The operation ended up being a profound success the fire impacted none of the infrastructure at Mount Wilson. Firefighters also picked up the few small spot fires that had the potential to ignite the other side of the ridge.

Rafeedy was quick to point out just how technical this operation wasit required quick thinking and the right assortment of resources, with a high-level understanding of fire behavior and how to use strategic firing operations to protect structures effectively.

"The crews performed this operation with a lot of expertise and good timing and even maturity is what I would call it," Rafeedy said. "They had the experience to do it well...and we were able to immediately start mopping up and catching slop overs."

While federal crews performed the operation, state and county crews assisted with holding the fire below the ridge. They picked up hot spots and made sure the fire stayed exactly where they wanted it.

"We had a plan in place and implemented it when it was time, not too soon and not too late," Rafeedy added. "These crews did what they're trained to do while working well with other resources. It couldn't have gone better."

The actions taken to protect Mount Wilson represent the most fundamental tool that firefighters have when fighting fire modifying the vegetation so it can better withstand fire. In these circumstances, it helps to do this type of work before a fire impacts an area.

Using fire to prepare for fire

The USDA Forest Service is leading the nation to make prescribed fires safer and more effective. We know that to protect communities and natural resources, we need to restore healthy, resilient, fire-adapted forests by using mechanical thinning and returning beneficial fires to these landscapes. Our work has taught us that we must work in the right places in the right ways to achieve the greatest good for both people and the environment.

These lessons certainly bore fruit on Mount Wilson, where the Forest Service had completed a number of fuels projects prior to the Eaton Fire, reducing fire intensity by limiting the amount of fuel present to burn.

These treatments have been taking place for decades, according to Angeles National Forest Fire Chief Robert Garcia.

"Being identified as a high-risk landscape gave us the opportunity during the last two years to really ramp up our efforts increasing the pace and scale of how much work we're doing and where we're doing that work," Garcia said.

"The investments we made for years, even decades, in a combination of treatments at Mount Wilson really paid off, especially since Mount Wilson has been threatened by several large fires just in the last couple of years with the Bobcat, the Bridge and now the Eaton Fire," he continued.

With this history of wildfire in the Angeles National Forest, Garcia recognizes that more work is needed to prepare for the next one, whenever it may come.

"I think this is an example of the need for an all-hands, all-levels-of-government approach," Garcia said. "Because there is no silver bullet, there is no simple treatment. But all these different pieces are part of the solution the fuels and vegetation management, the home hardening, ordinances around construction and how we respond together in a unified way."

urn:contentItem:6FFX-9V83-RSMD-N53V-00000-00MORNING UPDATE ON THE BLACK COVE COMPLEX IN POLK AND HENDERSON COUNTIES2025-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:17:28ZLexisNexisMORNING UPDATE ON THE BLACK COVE COMPLEX IN POLK AND HENDERSON COUNTIES

RALEIGH, N.C., March 28 -- The North Carolina Forest Service issued the following news release:

The Black Cove Complex currently has more than 500 personnel from North Carolina and other states across the nation supporting this incident.

A Red Flag Warning was issued for the area due to increased temperature, low humidity and increased winds, conditions favorable for fire progression. Rain chances increase early next week ahead of a cold front that will approach the region Sunday before crossing the area Monday.

Excessive storm debris and timber damage from Hurricane Helene has created many challenges for firefighting efforts. One factor is the loss off tree canopy. More ground cover is receiving direct sunlight, accelerating the rate in which fuels dry out.

---------------

Black Cove Fire: Currently, the Black Cove Fire is 3,288 acres in size and 17% contained. The fire is burning in timber on state-owned and private land, approximately 2 miles northeast of Saluda, in the Green River Gorge.

Fire behavior has continued to be intense, with rapid fire spread and extreme burning conditions due to shifting winds and dry weather throughout the day. The southwest portion of Black Cove remains a priority to secure the fire perimeter and protect homes within the Skyland Acres area. Strategic firing operations continued throughout the night to remove unburned fuels between containment lines and fire area around the Skyland Acres area. Due to the high relative humidity recovery last night, firing operations had minimal fire activity which led to a safe and slow burn which concluded at 3 a.m.

The Black Cove Fire was first reported Wednesday, March 19. The cause of this fire was determined to be a downed powerline.

Deep Woods Fire: Currently, the Deep Woods Fire is 3,373 acres in size and 30% contained. The fire is burning approximately 5 miles northwest of Columbus in timber on state-owned and private land in the Green River Gorge and in the neighboring Holbert Cove community.

A combination of bulldozer and hand lines were utilized on the southeastern portion of the fire close to the Green River. By utilizing the containment lines, firefighters were able to complete successful strategic firing operations to protect homes close to Green River Road. The purpose of the firing operation is to bring strategic and slow-moving fire within the unburned fuels with the lower temperatures and elevated humidity levels overnight. A combination of wildland firefighters and structural firefighters were present throughout the night to ensure firing operations were safe and successful. Firefighters throughout the day shift will hold and strengthen this line.

The Deep Woods Fire was first reported Wednesday, March 19. The cause of the fire remains under investigation.

Fish Hook Fire: Currently, the Fish Hook Fire is 199 acres in size and 95% contained. The fire is burning approximately 5 miles northwest of Mill Spring on private land near Lake Adger.

Firefighting personnel have stopped forward progress of the fire and continue securing firebreaks along the fire's edges and extinguishing smoldering fuels. Containment is expected to increase in the coming days, and firefighters will remain on scene until the fire no longer poses a threat.

The Fish Hook fire was first reported Thursday, March 20. The cause of this fire was determined to be a downed powerline.

---------------

Community Meeting: On Thursday, March 27 at 6 p.m., the city of Saluda hosted a community meeting for Saluda residents. Fire managers and emergency officials attended to provide updates on the Black Cove, Deep Woods and Fish Hook fires. For those unable to attend the meeting, the city of Saluda recorded it and will make it available for viewing via their website. A link will be provided once it becomes available.

Evacuations: Evacuation levels are constantly being assessed based on fire activity. For updated or current evacuation notices for Polk County, please refer to Polk County's website. For updated or current evacuation notices for Henderson County, please refer to Henderson County's website.

Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR): A TFR is in place at an altitude from the surface up to and including 5,500 feet, daily (24 hours) until further notice. Firefighting aircraft that respond to wildfires fly low in support of ground personnel. Drones can pose a serious threat to pilot and public safety. A drone that disrupts air operations also puts firefighters, residents and property at risk of loss to wildfire.

State of Emergency: On Tuesday, March 26, Governor Josh Stein declared a State of Emergency to expand the state's capacity to respond to the wildfires burning in Western North Carolina.

Statewide Ban on Open Burning: Effective 8 a.m. Friday, March 21, a ban on all open burning was issued statewide. All burning permits are canceled. No new permits are being issued. The ban remains in effect until further notice. NEW YORK, NY - MARCH 13: Traffic on Sixth Avenue passes by advertisements featuring Fox News personalities on the front of the News Corporation building, March 13, 2019 in New York City (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)

In a pair of competing and stinging court filings, Fox News and voting machine company Smartmatic Corp aimed to convince a judge that each side had the upper hand in a long-running defamation battle.

On Wednesday, in memorandums of law in support of respective motions for summary judgment filed in New York Supreme Court, both defendant and plaintiff savaged the other in no uncertain terms.

In the Fox News filing, attorneys argued the voting machine company was using the legal process to shore up its flagging business.

'[T]his lawsuit was manufactured to chill speech and generate headlines by a failing election company that was in financial free fall and saw allegations made by the President's lawyers as a pathway to profitability,' the filing reads.

In service of this effort, Fox News directly contrasted Smartmatic with Dominion - the other big name voting machine company embroiled in false and unsupported conspiracy theories about the 2020 election.

'Smartmatic's strategy in this case has been to draft behind the rulings in the Dominion lawsuit,' the Fox News filing goes on. 'But years of discovery have confirmed one thing above all else: Smartmatic is not Dominion.'

In April 2023, Fox News agreed to pay Dominion some $787.5 million in order to settle a defamation lawsuit. In that lawsuit, Dominion claimed Fox News knowingly smeared them with false claims - turning the 'flame' of election fraud lies into a 'forest fire.'

Yet, for the network, the two similarly-themed defamation lawsuits are something not entirely unlike wholly dissimilar. That's because of who the plaintiffs are, according to Fox News.

'Unlike Dominion, Smartmatic was a failing business without a significant presence in the United States entering the 2020 Presidential Election,' the Fox News filing continues. 'Unlike Dominion, Smartmatic was mired in a decade of business failure due to inadequate technology, missing certifications, and involvement in multiple highly controversial elections. Unlike Dominion, Smartmatic was founded by Venezuelans and was embroiled in claims of fraud in Venezuelan and Filipino elections well before any controversy arose over the 2020 Presidential Election.'

Related Coverage:

In the Smartmatic memo, the company sticks to its guns and reiterated, in strong language, the heart of its lawsuit: that Fox News aired false claims and 'election conspiracy theories' about its voting machines during post-2020 election coverage.

'Fox deliberately deceived its audience with utter contempt,' the company's filing begins.

The locus of this contempt, Smartmatic argues, was not just airing the alleged conspiracy theories - but airing such unsupported claims while allegedly knowing they were false.

'Fox News systematically promoted the inflammatory and false narrative that Smartmatic - smeared as a dirty Venezuelan company - had deployed software throughout the United States to steal votes from President Trump,' the Smartmatic filing continues. 'The Murdochs and their executives believed this was a story that President Trump's supporters wanted to hear, so that is what Fox News told them even though no one believed it to be true.'

The Smartmatic filing describes Fox News' actions as an intentional smear campaign waged to maintain the loyalty of a pro-Trump audience.

From the filing, at length:

Fox's decision to embrace, endorse, and amplify baseless election fraud claims became known as the 'pivot.' Before the pivot, the Murdochs directed Fox News towards neutral ground regarding the 2020 election, which included allowing the Decision Desk to be the first to call Arizona for Joe Biden. But that call resulted in an unprecedented backlash against Fox News from President Trump, his supporters, and its previously loyal audience. Facing that backlash, the Murdochs and Fox News' CEO decided to 'pivot' and lean into election fraud claims they personally believed were baseless. After the 'pivot,' dissenters within Fox who wanted to tell the audience the truth were punished, employees associated with the Arizona call were fired, and advocates for election fraud claims were promoted and highlighted. After the pivot, for one month, Fox pushed the narrative that Smartmatic (a company that only operated in Los Angeles County) had participated in a criminal conspiracy to rig the 2020 election.

Filed in 2021, the underlying lawsuit - and Wednesday's filing - allege that top brass at the network were able to reap a financial windfall while Smartmatic suffered the opposite fate.

'Fox News' 'pivot' was designed to boost ratings, which it did,' the Smartmatic filing goes on. 'Good for Fox. It devastated Smartmatic. After decades of successful elections worldwide, Smartmatic believed its groundbreaking work with Los Angeles County would serve as a springboard for future success in the United States and globally. That did not happen.'

Instead, the voting machine company says, its employees received 'chilling' threats against their lives while Smartmatic itself found its business prospects and reputation 'destroyed,' according to the filing.

'Over 100 employees have lost their jobs,' the Smartmatic filing claims. 'Billions in value have forever been lost. None of this had to happen. And none of it would have happened if those in charge of Fox cared about Fox News telling the truth or the consequences of falsely accusing a company of committing one of the biggest crimes in history.'

Fox News, for its part, argues Smartmatic's reputational issues are problems of its own making.

'Election-integrity controversies have followed Smartmatic around the world, including in Venezuela and the Philippines, and in the U.S. where Smartmatic had to beat an ignominious retreat in 2006 following a federal national-security investigation,' the Fox News filing claims. 'Smartmatic was then boxed out of meaningful U.S. business opportunities because it lacked the necessary product certifications and technologies to compete. In 2020, it had just one U.S. client. Internationally, customers repeatedly rejected Smartmatic's deficient products and services.'

Each of the filings contains multiple pages of redactions; those redactions are made in line with a preexisting confidentiality agreement in the case.

Fox News, in its filing, offered an overview of its defenses. The network claims that Smartmatic has no valid damages, that there is no basis for punitive damages, that no defamatory statements were aired with actual malice, that the company itself cannot be held liable for relevant publication decisions, and that they are entitled to summary judgment under New York's anti-SLAPP - or strategic lawsuit against public participation - law, which can end a defamation lawsuit if a court determines said lawsuit is an effort to chill free speech.

In its own overview, Smartmatic claims Fox News did not merely exaggerate but fabricated claims about election rigging, that Fox News is liable for defamation per se, that Fox News is, in fact, liable for publishing election fraud lies, that those alleged lies were spread with actual malice, and that Fox News is not eligible for the 'fair reporting' privilege - which can mitigate liability when a publisher relays a fair and accurate account of an official document or proceeding.

Both Fox News and Smartmatic also traded dueling statements in response to inquiries from Law&Crime.

'The evidence shows that Smartmatic's business and reputation were badly suffering long before any claims by President Trump's lawyers on Fox News and that Smartmatic grossly inflated its damage claims to generate headlines and chill free speech,' a Fox News spokesperson said in an email. 'Now, in the aftermath of Smartmatic's executives getting indicted for bribery charges, we are eager and ready to continue defending our press freedoms.'

Smartmatic's lead attorney, Erik Connolly, offered the voting machine company's strongly-worded take on the filings in an email.

'Fox is running the same playbook as other abusers, trying to sully the victim,' Connolly said. 'Fox cannot justify its month-long smear campaign against Smartmatic. Everyone from the Murdochs to the show producers knew they were pushing baseless claims. So, Fox is piling new lies on top of its old ones to try to persuade shareholders that its financial exposure is less than the $780 million paid to Dominion. It is not. It is much more. Fox will be held accountable. Fox's motion is a distraction, not a defense.'

Extended datais available for this paper at https://doi.org/10.1038/s41561-025-01730-3.Publisher’s note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Wildfires reduce vegetation cover and soil biocrust, thus expanding bare grounds susceptible to wind erosion. However, global characterization of post-fire dust emissions has remained qualitative and focused only on landscapes disturbed by relatively large wildfires. Here we apply principles of fluid mechanics to satellite measurements to quantify post-fire dust emissions. We find that 61% of global wildfires at various extents are followed by enhanced dust emissions, injecting 5.6 (3.3–9.2) Tg of dust per year during 2003 to 2022. 95% of the post-fire dust emissions are sourced to small wildfires, which occur more frequently and broadly than large wildfires especially across sparsely vegetated regions. Despite the recent decline in global burned area and a resultant decreasing occurrence of post-fire dust events, the total amount of global post-fire dust emissions has increased by 77% during the last two decades. This elevation in total post-fire dust emissions is attributed to intensifying burning and worsening fire-induced land degradation, which trigger a 155% increase in the intensity of post-fire dust emissions. With an ongoing enhancement of extreme wildfires and synchronized droughts under global warming, our results indicate the emerging importance of post-fire dust emissions globally and regionally.

Post-fire dust emissions have increased by 77% globally over the past two decades, and small fires account for 95% of these emissions, according to analysis of satellite observations.

MainWildfires present an essential disturbance to the Earth’s terrestrial ecosystem, capable of destroying vegetation cover1,2, biocrust3,4 and reducing soil moisture5,6, thus expanding bare grounds susceptible to wind erosion7,8. On the basis of in situ measurements, past studies have shown cases of post-fire landscapes becoming temporary dust sources9, 10–11. Using a combination of multiple satellite observations, Yu and Ginoux12 corroborated post-fire dust emissions on a global scale. They estimated that ~54% of large wildfires are followed by enhanced dust emissions, even over normally dust-free regions. This phenomenon has been reconfirmed by recent studies with more observational data13,14.

One key uncertainty in Yu and Ginoux12 is the omission of small wildfires. Although the analysed satellite observations well captured the enhanced dust emissions following the wildfires during the 20109 and 201210 burning seasons in the western United States, as reported by previous in situ and modelling studies, these two events have indeed been excluded from the inventory of post-fire dust events in Yu and Ginoux12 due to their relatively small extent of precedent fires (Extended Data Fig. 1). However, small fires naturally occur more frequently than large fires, imposing more spread-out influence on the terrestrial ecosystem15,16. For example, it has been found that small fires account for nearly half of the burned area and carbon emissions in Africa17. Furthermore, in contrast with large fires that tend to occur in moderately to densely vegetated regions, small fires are more likely to occur over sparsely vegetated areas that are generally more prone to wind erosion18. Therefore, dust emissions from small-fire-disturbed landscapes need to be assessed but with caution, especially for a false-positive signal of transported dust from nearby drylands.

Recent trends and future projections in fire occurrence and intensity have posed a question on the trajectory of post-fire dust emissions. Agricultural expansion has led to a steep drop in fire activities, with the global burned area declining by nearly one-quarter over the first 15 years of the twenty-first century19. Conversely, the ongoing global warming may increase future fire risks, resulting in elevated severity of burning20,21. As a part of the risingly severe fire-related environmental concerns, post-fire dust potentially imposes greater socio-economic and health impacts than dryland dust, due to its closer location to populated areas12,22. Given these climatic and socio-economic influences of post-fire dust, there is a need to quantify the emissions of post-fire dust and their trends.

To fill the aforementioned knowledge gaps, the current study aims to (1) identify global hotspots of dust emissions following wildfires at various extents, (2) quantify the regional and global post-fire dust emissions and (3) diagnose the recent trends in post-fire dust emissions and their potential driving mechanisms. We improve the identification process of post-fire dust events applied in Yu and Ginoux12, especially by filtering dust advection from non-local sources using principles from fluid mechanics (Methods). On the basis of satellite observations of active fires, vegetation cover and aerosol abundance and characteristics, we first identify fire events at various extents, as indicated by cumulative active fires within each 0.1° pixel in consecutive seven days and then search for localized dust load anomalies during the vegetation recovery period (Methods). This improved approach allows us to compare dust emissions following small fires (≤20 active fires during consecutive seven days per 0.1° pixel) with those following large fires (>20 active fires during consecutive seven days per 0.1° pixel); the latter were qualitatively examined in Yu and Ginoux12. Subsequently, we analyse the post-fire dust emissions on a global scale and assess its recent trend integrated over hydrological, climate and continental regions.

A more complete picture of global post-fire dust emissions

On the basis of the examined satellite observations of fire, vegetation and aerosols over the 20-year period from 2003 to 2022 (Methods), we identify 20,262,579 fire events at various extents on a global scale. Among the analysed fire events, 84% and 61% are followed by significant reduction in enhanced vegetation index (EVI) and consequent dust events, respectively, during the subsequent vegetation recovery period (Extended Data Fig. 2). These 12,402,418 post-fire dust events are distributed across 188,423 0.1° pixels, spanning over 12% of Earth’s land surface. The most intensive post-fire dust emissions primarily occur in semi-arid regions in central Africa, southwestern North America, southern Asia, the intersection of Asia and Europe and sporadic areas in eastern Asia, northern and southeastern Australia, with the maximum amount of post-fire dust emissions over 0.1° pixel ranging up to 1,679.6 tons per year (Fig. 1a). Among these hotspot regions, dust emissions following wildfires has been detected for up to 113 days per year; whereas in the majority of global burnable areas, post-fire dust emissions typically occur on 1–11 days per year (Extended Data Fig. 3a,b).Fig. 1

With additional input of dust mass extinction efficiency and dust lifetime as provided by multiple ensembles of global aerosol and Earth system model simulations, we quantify the amount of post-fire dust emissions (Methods). Approximately 5.6 (3.3–9.2 among different years) Tg of dust particles are emitted from fire-disturbed landscapes per year (Extended Data Fig. 4g), ~89% of which are sourced from arid and semi-arid regions (Fig. 1a). Additionally, the semi-arid tropical savannahs in Africa between 5 N° and 15 N° are the largest post-fire dust sources in the world, accounting for nearly 40% of global total post-fire dust emissions by mass (Fig. 1a). Therefore, in contrast to dryland dust that primarily spreads over northern subtropics and mid-latitudes, post-fire dust is mainly distributed in areas near the Equator (Fig. 1b).

The currently analysed models and datasets consistently show a contribution of ~0.28% (0.21–0.35% among datasets), or ~6.1 Tg (4.1–10.0 Tg among datasets), to global annual dust emissions by post-fire dust events (Extended Data Fig. 5). Africa is the leading source of dust emissions following wildfires, accounting for ~59.2% of worldwide post-fire dust emissions, followed by Asia (~20.9%), Europe (~7.9%), Americas (~7.2%) and Oceania (~4.8%) (Extended Data Table 1). Due to the regionally high occurrence and severity of wildfires, post-fire dust in the Americas and Australia accounts for a larger fraction of regional dust emissions than the global average, at about 0.19–1.28% and 0.31–1.20%, respectively (Extended Data Fig. 5e–i).

Small fires dominate global post-fire dust emissions

Cumulative dust emissions following small fire events outweigh those following large fire events by a factor of 18.2 during the studied years, indicating the crucial role of small fires in global post-fire dust emissions (Fig. 1b). Indeed, over 85% of the identified post-fire dust events are triggered by no more than ten active fires detected within a 0.1° pixel during the precedent burning period (Extended Data Fig. 3c). Particularly, latitudes (5° N–15° N) most prone to post-fire dust activities have experienced no more than eight active fires per pixel per event before the emission of dust on average (Extended Data Fig. 3d). Furthermore, similar spatial distributions are obtained between total post-fire dust emissions (Fig. 1a) and those following small fires (Extended Data Fig. 4a). That is, post-fire dust emissions are primarily sourced from small-fire-disturbed landscapes.

The overwhelming amount of dust emissions following small fires is a natural outcome of small fires’ higher frequency and broader extent (Fig. 2). Averaged over the analysed pixels and across the analysed two decades, the occurrence of wildfire events decreases exponentially with increasing extent of burning (Fig. 2a). The currently analysed smallest fires, defined as those with one 1 km × 1 km active burning spot detected within a 0.1° × 0.1° pixel during consecutive seven days, occur 1.65 times per year per pixel; whereas large fires, with over 20 active burning spots detected within the same time–space window, occur only 0.05 times per year per pixel (Fig. 2a). As a result, the occurrence of post-fire dust events following small fires is nearly two orders of magnitude higher than that following large fires (Fig. 2b), decreasing exponentially from 0.96 post-fire dust events per pixel per year following the aforementioned smallest fires to 0.03 post-fire dust events per pixel per year following the large fires (Fig. 2a). Moreover, the background EVI and soil moisture shows wider probability distributions associated with small fires than that associated with large fires (significant difference confirmed by Kolmogorov–Smirnov test with p values < 0.01), especially in sparse-vegetation dryland regions and dense-vegetation humid regions (Fig. 2c,d), confirming the previously reported abundance of small fires across the sparsely vegetated tundra23 and alpine24, to moderately vegetated grasslands and savannahs25, to densely vegetated tropical rainforests26. Thereby, orders of-magnitude higher occurrence of small fires, especially over sparsely vegetated drylands, supports higher amounts of post-fire dust emitted from small-fire-disturbed landscapes (Fig. 2c,d).Fig. 2

On the other hand, the intensity of post-fire dust emissions shows a direct response to post-fire vegetation abundance and soil moisture, regardless of its pre-fire state or fire-induced reductions (Fig. 2c–f). Particularly, the intensity of post-fire dust emission, from landscapes with similar levels of post-fire EVI and soil moisture, varies little with the extent of precedent burning (Fig. 2e,f) and consistently reaches its maximum with post-fire EVI and soil moisture below 0.15 and 0.15 m3 m−3, respectively (Fig. 2e,f). Therefore, in spite that small fires generally result in weaker land surface disturbances, a climatologically dry, sparsely vegetated landscape is easily degraded to an erodible landscape, accomplished mainly by frequent, small fires.

Post-fire dust emissions getting stronger

During 2003–2022, most Köppen–Geiger climate regions have experienced a significant, negative trend (p values < 0.1) in the occurrence of post-fire dust events (Fig. 3a–c), with a total reduction of 193,961 (~30%) cases during the last two decades. This decline is more substantial over low-latitude, semi-arid regions, especially in Africa, the leading continent of post-fire dust emissions. Such reduced occurrence of post-fire dust events is attributed to the decrease in fire occurrence (Extended Data Fig. 6a–c), consistent with the observed global decline in burned areas due to agricultural expansion19. Notably, the occurrence of post-fire dust events disturbed by small fires decreases more significantly compared to those disturbed by large fires (Fig. 3b,c).Fig. 3

Despite the recent reduction of post-fire dust events, an increasing amount of dust is emitted from post-fire landscapes, especially from areas disturbed by small fires (Fig. 3d–f). For the presently examined tropical, arid, temperate and cold regions, the amount of post-fire dust emissions increases by 0.27, 0.18, 0.09 and 0.56 Tg, corresponding to a regional percentage increase of 70.5%, 77.5%, 38.8% and 274.2%, respectively, during the last two decades, with p values lower than 0.1 except for the tropical region. Additionally, post-fire dust emissions caused by small fires increase more significantly compared to those by large fires (Fig. 3e,f), with the former dominating the increase in total post-fire dust emissions in the entire globe (Fig. 3d,e).

The combination of a reduced occurrence (Fig. 3a–c), albeit an increased total amount of post-fire dust emissions (Fig. 3d–f), suggests recently intensifying dust emissions from individual post-fire events (Fig. 3g–i). The intensity of dust emissions following all fire events has increased globally, with a regional increase of 137.1%, 168.4%, 82.0% and 701.2% for the presently examined tropical, arid, temperate and cold regions during the past two decades. These recent changes in the intensity of post-fire dust emissions are controlled by the variation in post-fire vegetation cover and soil moisture (as shown in Fig. 2e,f). During recent years, a delayed vegetation recovery from fires in high latitudes (Extended Data Fig. 7a–c) in phase with an intensified regional burning (as reflected by fire radiative power; Extended Data Fig. 6d–f), alongside an extended period of post-fire soil dryness in mid- to low latitudes (Extended Data Fig. 8a–c), provide elucidation on the heightened intensity of post-fire dust emissions globally.

Uncertainties insensitive to fire extent or year

The uncertainties of the current results first derive from the identification of post-fire dust emissions, especially the filtering of dust advection. Our validation tests (Methods) have confirmed the general success in filtering non-local dust, as supported by a maximum-likelihood probability of only 26.4% of making false-positive mistakes (Fig. 4a,b). Furthermore, ~71.1% of post-fire dust can be detected in the near-surface layer (0–2 km) by space-borne lidar (Methods), suggestive of local sources associated with the majority of identified post-fire dust events. However, our validation tests also suggest that the methodology used for filtering dust advection from non-local sources appears overly stringent, with a maximum-likelihood probability of 75.6% of making false-negative mistakes (Fig. 4c,d). Nevertheless, small and large fires exhibit insignificant differences (both p values greater than 0.5 according to Kolmogorov–Smirnov test) or trends (all four p values greater than 0.1 according to Mann–Kendall test) in their post-fire windiness and dust aerosol clustering, ensuring the independence of the uncertainty with post-fire dust emissions identification upon the extent of precedent fires and study year.Fig. 4

Uncertainties are also embedded with the quantification process of post-fire dust emissions. The conversion of dust optical depth (DOD) to dust emissions involves several simplifications and probably provides a lower limit of post-fire dust emissions (Methods). Although the mass extinction efficiency and dust lifetime we use are close to the median values derived from theoretical calculations and multiple Earth system models27, 28–29, possible temporal and spatial variations in these parameters may introduce bias to our estimates. Future efforts are critically needed to assess these spatio-temporal variations of mass extinction efficiency and dust lifetime, narrowing the present, wide spread of these variables among models and datasets as shown in Extended Data Table 1.

Furthermore, MODIS DOD data coverage is sensitive to cloud cover (Extended Data Fig. 9) and therefore insufficient for identifying post-fire dust emissions with the presence of cloud. Yet the MODIS data coverage shows relatively weak trends during the past two decades (Extended Data Fig. 9), facilitating meaningful trend analysis with this data.

Overall, the current study probably highly underestimates post-fire dust emissions, but to similar extents for dust emissions following small and large fires and among different years. Precise quantification of post-fire dust emissions, along with their long-term changes and environmental impacts, will be achieved through experiments within chemical transport and Earth system models.

Implications for the future of post-fire dust emissions

Our findings reveal that post-fire dust emissions are primarily sourced from landscapes disturbed by small fires as a result of small fires’ wider spatio-temporal distribution. However, it should be noted that our definition of small fire, based on 1-km-resolution MODIS images, differs from previous studies using higher resolution satellite-based detection of fires in Africa15,30, partially due to the present lack of a finer-resolution satellite aerosol measurement (Methods). Current and future developments in satellite-based detections of both aerosols and fires at higher spatial and temporal resolutions will unfold an even more complete picture of post-fire dust emissions.

The recent two decades’ intensification of post-fire dust emissions is an outcome of the worsening post-fire land surface degradations. In particular, the post-fire EVI over high latitudes have experienced a significant decrease (Extended Data Fig. 7a–c), opposing the pre-fire greening trend (Extended Data Fig. 7d–f) as previously reported in a wider geographical scope31,32; this post-fire browning is probably due to the regional combination of minimal changes in the occurrence of fire events (Extended Data Fig. 6a–c), increased burning intensities (Extended Data Fig. 6d–f)33 and slower recovery of the terrestrial ecosystems from fires34. On the other hand, the trends in pre-fire soil moisture (Extended Data Fig. 8d–f) during 2003–2022 seem to resemble the previously reported ‘dry-gets-drier, wet-gets-wetter’ pattern under global warming35. In sum, the recent intensification of post-fire dust emissions is associated with land surface responses to both hydroclimatic changes and wildfire regime shifts.

The long-term trajectory of post-fire dust emissions is thus governed by the intertwined changes in the atmospheric and terrestrial systems. Although the decline in burned area caused by agricultural expansion has temporarily counterbalanced climate risks19, the continued global warming is highly likely to increase wildfire frequency in the future20,36,37. Additionally, as warming weakens the night-time barrier to wildfires, extremely large fires are more likely to occur33, probably resulting in more dust emissions from those burned landscapes. Meanwhile, a possibly even drier future for the semi-arid lands38,39, potentially with longer-than-expected dry spells40, also presents a potential for even slower land surface recovery from fire-induced disturbances and thus a further heightened intensity of post-fire dust emissions. Overall, our study calls for attention to the ongoing increase in post-fire dust emissions with global climate and environmental changes.

Methods

Satellite-based measurements of dust and other aerosols

DOD is a column integration of extinction coefficient by mineral particles and describes changes in dustiness. Following Pu et al.29, the current study examines DOD retrieved from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on board the Terra and Aqua satellites as follows:1where AOD is aerosol optical depth, α is the Ångström exponent and ω is single-scattering albedo. The above variables are obtained from collection 6.1, level 2 MODIS Deep Blue aerosol products42,43, and first interpolated to a 0.1° × 0.1° grid using the algorithm described by Ginoux et al.44. The single-scattering albedo at 470 nm is required to be less than 0.99 to account for dust’s absorption of solar radiation and separate dust from purely scattering aerosols, such as sea salt. The continuous function of AOD and Ångström exponent is based on the size distribution of dust towards the coarse range and to separate it from fine particles45,46; therefore, MODIS DOD represents the optical depth of absorbing, coarse-mode aerosols that are often dust over bare ground or sparsely vegetated regions. Besides, Baddock et al.47 found that dust sources are better detected using DOD with a low-quality flag (that is, QA = 1) than high-quality flag (that is, QA = 3), and thus DOD with flag of QA = 1 is used in this study. MODIS DOD products have been widely applied to identify dust sources44, characterize dust variation48,49 and model intercomparison50.

Fine-mode optical depth (FOD) is the residual of total AOD after subtracting DOD, which indicates the abundance of aerosols with relatively fine sizes, primarily smoke aerosols over active fires. Notably, due to the spatial resolution limitations of MODIS aerosol products, the current study is conducted at 0.1° × 0.1° longitude–latitude grid (approximately 123 km2 per grid near the Equator), which may not be optimal for accurately representing fire, dust and contemporaneous changes in environmental structures over complex landscapes.

Satellite-based measurements of wildfire extent and intensity

Active fire product51 derived from the MODIS on board the Terra and Aqua satellites is analysed here for assessing the intensity of wildfires. The contextual algorithms used by the MODIS Collection 6.1 Active fire detections identify fires in 1-km pixels on the basis of the thermal anomalies. If the difference of temperature between the actively burning areas and neighbour land cover is above a given threshold, the potential fire is confirmed as an active fire. In the current study, daily wildfire extent is represented as the total active fire counts from both the daytime and night-time MODIS measurements, and wildfire intensity is assessed by the daily total fire radiative power. Corresponding to the spatial resolution of analysed aerosol data, the original 1-km active fire product is interpolated to a 0.1° × 0.1° grid using the algorithm described by Ginoux et al.44.

Satellite-based measurements of vegetation cover and soil moisture

To explore the variations in vegetation cover and soil moisture disturbed by wildfires, the current study analyses the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from MODIS Collection 652 and soil moisture from European Space Agency’s (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (CCI) project v08.1 product53. On the basis of spectral responses from the red, near-infrared and blue wavebands, the MODIS EVI can reflect vegetation greenness, thereby effectively monitoring Earth’s terrestrial photosynthetic vegetation activity. Compared with the standard Normalized Difference Vegetation Index from MODIS, EVI shows improved capability to minimize canopy–soil variations and enhanced sensitivity over dense-vegetation regions. Given the MODIS sensors aboard on Aqua and Terra provide 16-day EVI composite eight days apart from both satellites, here we combine the data records to obtain a higher temporal resolution (8-day) product. ESA CCI soil moisture is a quality-controlled muti-decadal (1978–2022) dataset merging soil moisture retrievals from various single-sensor active and passive microwaves into three products: ACTIVE, PASSIVE and COMBINED. The COMBINED product is used in this study to examine soil moisture in the top layer, which is integrated by ACTIVE and PASSIVE datasets following a ternary decision scheme. We obtain collocated 0.25° daily soil moisture and 1-km 8-day EVI data for the nearest grid to the location of the dust pixel.

Identification of post-fire dust emissions

The post-fire dust events are identified following these steps:

We screen the daily 0.1° active fire count data to identify fire events at various extents during 2003–2022. If the cumulative active fire count in a pixel exceeds a given threshold in consecutive seven days, the location–time combination is defined as a fire event. To prioritize the identification of large fire events over small fire events, the thresholds are set in descending order (from 20 to 1).

Among these fire events at various extents, we identify those with significant vegetation reduction, that is, any 8-day EVI falling below the 10th percentile of the long-term spread during the subsequent recovery period after the end of burning and before the EVI exceeds its long-term 10th percentile for a continuous 16 days (Extended Data Fig. 2). The long-term spread for a specific 0.1° pixel on a particular date of year is obtained by aggregating all EVI measurements within ±15 days of that date for that pixel during 2003–2022.

Among those fire events that induce significant vegetation reduction, we examine daily DOD and FOD measurements during the subsequent vegetation recovery period. A day with moderate-to-high DOD (exceeding the 50th percentile of long-term spread and the climatology of DOD for the corresponding month) from either morning or afternoon measurements along with concurrent moderate-to-low FOD (below the 50th percentile of long-term spread) from both the morning and afternoon measurements is considered as a potential post-fire dust emissions day. High FOD situation is excluded to minimize contamination of flying ash and smoke aerosols over active fires on the DOD signal, as flying ash and smoke aerosols are mostly smaller particles compared with dust. Whereas dust and other particles emitted during fire could possibly be lifted by pyroconvection to high altitudes and stay in the atmosphere for several days54, these during-fire dust emissions are assumed to exert minimal influence on the current identification of post-fire dust emissions because of the former’s co-presence with fine particles and resultant tendency of being excluded due to high FOD. The long-term spread of DOD and FOD for a specific 0.1° pixel on a particular date are aggregated from both MODIS Terra and MODIS Aqua within ±15 days of that date for that pixel during 2003–2022.

To ensure that the identified post-fire dust emissions are disturbed by local wildfires rather than transported dust, we filter out cases with likely non-local dust sources. That is, among potential post-fire dust emission cases, only those with DOD values at the burned pixel exceeding those of the surrounding eight pixels are confirmed as genuine post-fire dust emission cases.

Compared with the identification of post-fire dust events applied in Yu and Ginoux12, methodological changes in the current study are summarized as follows. First, accounting for dust emissions following all fire events, rather than those solely following large fire events, results in an exponential increase in the total post-fire dust emissions but the relatively stable portion of local dust (Extended Data Fig. 4e–g). Secondly, the criterion for identifying dust anomalies is lowered from the 90th percentile to the 50th percentile of the long-term spread, thus moderate-to-high levels of enhanced post-fire dust emissions are encompassed in this study. Nevertheless, the majority of the identified dust anomalies are from those extreme DODs exceeding the long-term 90th percentile (Extended Data Fig. 4c–d). Specifically, 66.5 ± 10.5%, 24.1 ± 4.0% and 9.4 ± 3.9% of the post-fire dust emissions can be attributed to the dust anomalies falling within the 100th–90th, 90th–70th and 70th–50th, respectively, percentiles of long-term spread. Third, the influence of transported dust is filtered by screening out post-fire DOD anomalies lower than DOD in any of the surrounding eight pixels. Consequently, approximately 51.9 ± 1.1% of post-fire dust anomalies are identified as transported dust (Extended Data Fig. 4e–g), which are excluded from the current inventory of global post-fire dust emissions events. These filtered dust anomalies are primarily concentrated in regions near dryland dust sources, including the southern Sahara and Sahel, the Middle East and Central Asia, North America and so on (Extended Data Fig. 4b).

Aggregation of post-fire dust emissions by hydrological, climate and continental regions

Post-fire dust emissions are reported for different hydrological, climate and continental regions. The aridity index (AI) is a quantitative indicator of global dryness defined as the ratio of annual precipitation to annual potential evapotranspiration58. Here we examine the aridity index over the period of 2000–2022 using precipitation and potential evapotranspiration data at a spatial resolution of 0.25° from ERA559. Global land areas are grouped into five hydrological regions: hyper-arid (AI ≤ 0.05), arid (0.05 < AI ≤ 0.20), semi-arid (0.20 < AI ≤ 0.50), dry subhumid (0.50 < AI ≤ 0.65) and humid regions (AI > 0.65) (Extended Data Fig. 2a). The hyper-arid regions, mostly unvegetated grounds except for a few scattered shrubs, have been excluded in the current study. The climate regions are defined based on the 1-km Köppen–Geiger climate classifications map during 1980−2016 updated by Beck el al.60. The Köppen–Geiger system classifies climate into five main classes and 30 subtypes61 (Extended Data Fig. 2b and Extended Data Table 1), which capture biome distribution around the world with a combination of the precipitation and air temperature. The EF (polar, frost) region, covering mostly ice and snow, is excluded from our study. The continental regions are divided by standard area code according to the United Nations publication ‘Standard Country or Area Codes for Statistical Use’ (https://unstats.un.org/unsd/methodology/m49/). The global aridity index, Köppen–Geiger and continental data are all regridded to the same 0.1° grid as the aerosol data following Ginoux el al.44, and then post-fire dust emissions detected within 0.1° pixels are classified into corresponding hydrological, climate and continental regions.

Validation tests for the methodology of identifying local post-fire dust emissions

To minimize the potential contamination from transported dust, only DOD anomalies with local DOD exceeding adjacent DODs are attributed to local disturbance from wildfires in the current study. Whereas this methodology of distinguishing locally emitted from advected aerosols stems from principles in classic fluid mechanics, we conduct three validation tests using realistic data to semi-quantitatively estimate the uncertainty in our approach associated with false-positive and false-negative identifications.

In the first validation test, MODIS FOD, as a direct indicator of smoke aerosols emitted from wildfires, is examined to detect whether this method effectively filters smoke advection from non-local sources, thus validating the theoretical differentiation between advected and locally emitted aerosol. First, we screen the daily 0.1° MODIS FOD data to detect the abnormal smoke events, characterized by FOD in the centre pixel exceeding both the 50th percentile of its long-term spread and the concurrent FODs of the surrounding eight pixels. This step follows our identification of local, post-fire dust emissions events. Then we calculate the success rate of the above approach in matching the actual smoke source, that is, among these apparently local, abnormal smoke events, how often do we observe an active burning in the centre pixel that exceeds the fire counts from those in the surrounding eight pixels. A higher success rate indicates that the abundant smoke aerosols in the central pixel are more likely induced by local wildfires rather than transported smoke. Finally, we identify 324,078,033 abnormal smoke events globally during 2018–2022, with 67.6% of them being successfully matched to a local wildfire emissions source.

In the second test, we use space-borne lidar to distinguish between local versus advected dust, given their contrasting vertical distribution of aerosol features. Post-fire dust is generally near-surface dust sourced from disturbance of local wildfires; whereas transported dust typically distributes above 2 km, as it is uplifted to mid-to-high altitudes during long-range transportation62,63. Cloud-Aerosol Lidar and Infrared Pathfinder Satellite Operations (CALIPSO) is capable of observing the vertical distribution of aerosol subtypes64,65. To match with the spatial resolution of analysed aerosol data, daytime overpasses from CALIPSO Level 2 Vertical Feature Mask product version 4.51 during 2006–2022 are interpolated to a three-dimensional grid, with a horizontal resolution of 0.1° × 0.1° and vertical resolution consistent with the original products. Subsequently, we examine the presence of dust, polluted dust and dusty marine aerosols within 0–2 km at the location–time combination of the identified post-fire dust events. We obtain 11,362 corresponding CALIPSO observations that match our MODIS-based post-fire dust inventory globally during 2006–2022, 71.1% of which have detected the presence of dust within 0–2 km aboveground, suggesting that these dust anomalies are largely from local sources.

In the third test, we estimate the rate of false-negative mistakes in our approach. We also use FOD data as an analogy to evaluate our approach of capturing local aerosol sources. Here we first identify isolated wildfire events, with active fire counts in the centre pixel but not in the surrounding eight pixels. Subsequently, by observing whether these isolated wildfires lead to an abnormal FOD that exceeds those of the surrounding eight pixels, we can get a sense of how much actual local aerosol emissions are missed in our approach. We identify 2,928,414 isolated wildfire events globally during 2018–2022, 19.1% of which have resulted in an abnormal, local FOD signal based on our approach. That is, the false-negative rate of our approach to identify post-fire dust emissions is about 80.9%.

Finally, we use results from the above first and third tests to estimate the possibility of making false-positive and false-negative mistakes in our identification of post-fire dust emissions. We first attribute the spatio-temporal variations in false-positive and false-negative identifications of local aerosol emission to (1) low-level wind speed, directly affecting aerosol advection and (2) clustering of abundant aerosols, influencing the local distribution of aerosols. The analysis on low-level wind is done with daily 850-hPa horizontal wind from ERA5. The level of aerosol clustering is defined as the number of pixels with moderate-to-high FOD (>long-term 50th percentile) within ±0.5° of the burning pixel. Lower success rate (1-false-positive) and higher missing (false-negative) rate generally collocate with higher levels of low-level windiness and clustering of aerosol plumes (Fig. 4b,d). The obtained dependence of false-positive and false-negative rates on wind speed and aerosol clustering, noted as fp(wind, aerosol clustering) and fn(wind, aerosol clustering) (colour shading in Fig. 4b,d), are subsequently used to estimate the uncertainty levels associated with dust emissions identification following small and large fires. In the latter case, aerosol clustering is indicated by number of pixels with moderate-to-high DOD (>long-term 50th percentile) within ±0.5° of the burned pixel; wind speed is obtained during the subsequent vegetation recovery period. The combination of low-level wind and aerosol clustering that maximizes their joint probability density is separately retrieved from the identified dust events following small and large fires and plugged into fp(wind, aerosol clustering) and fn(wind, aerosol clustering). This approach results in nearly identical maximum-likelihood estimates of these rates (26.4% false positive and 75.6% false negative) between dust emissions identification following small and large fires (Fig. 4b,d).
